caption:
This photograph depicts an industrial setting, likely a steel mill or similar facility, under an overcast or dimly lit sky. The image is dominated by a complex of large, metallic structures, including silos, ducts, and elevated walkways or conveyors overhead. These industrial installations are constructed from metal, painted in fading colors, and show signs of wear and aging such as rust and peeling paint.

At the ground level, a muddy, wet road runs through the scene, reflecting the industrial function of the area. Puddles and debris can be seen on the ground, suggesting recent activity or rainfall. A red pickup truck is parked off to the left side, partially under one of the elevated walkways, which adds a touch of bright color to the otherwise drab environment.

The environment gives off a heavy, gritty feel typical of working industrial areas, with no visible vegetation or natural elements. The atmosphere suggests a cold or damp climate, contributing to the overall sense of a stark, utilitarian workspace. The photograph captures both the structural complexity and the rough aesthetic often associated with industrial zones.
title: Silica fume precipitate passes from a bag house to a silo to be loaded on trucks and taken to a landfill from the union carbide ferro-Alloy plant.  Between october, 1967, and september, 1975, total annual emissions were reduced 97.7 percent, from 113,252 to 2,649 tons a compliance schedule was reached between the company and the West Virginia air pollution control commission.  Epa stack sampled plant emissions while developing national new source performance standards.  (see fiche #141 to 146)
